verses.text: I said in my heart, “Come now, I will test you with pleasure. Enjoy yourself.” But see, this also was vanity.
verses.comment: Here the Teacher pursues pleasure to determine if fulfillment can be found in enjoyment. The word 'vanity' indicates fleeting emptiness, connecting to the theme of human pursuits—this challenge foreshadows later New Testament teaching about storing up eternal treasure (see Matt. 6:19-21).

verses.text: I said of laughter, 'It is mad,' and of pleasure, 'What does it accomplish?'
verses.comment: The Teacher condemns laughter and pleasure as pointless when detached from deeper meaning. Spiritual traditions often caution that true joy comes from communion with God rather than worldly entertainment.

verses.text: I searched in my heart how to cheer my body with wine—my heart still guiding me with wisdom—and how to lay hold on folly, till I might see what was good for people to do under heaven during the few days of their life.
verses.comment: This verse shows a mindful indulgence, not reckless; wisdom is kept nearby. The phrase 'few days of their life' echoes the brevity of mortal existence, reminding one of the need for spiritual discernment and true wisdom (see Ps. 90:12).

verses.text: I made great works; I built houses and planted vineyards for myself.
verses.comment: Here the Teacher emphasizes external achievements, reminiscent of Solomon’s historical grandeur, yet still searching for lasting satisfaction.

verses.text: I made gardens and parks, and planted in them all kinds of fruit trees.
verses.comment: The imagery recalls Eden and evokes Paradise lost and sought, underlying man's longing to restore that harmony with God—an implicit anticipation of restoration through Christ (see Rev. 22:1-2).

verses.text: I made pools of water, to water the forest of growing trees.
verses.comment: Water is a symbol of blessing and spiritual renewal (cf. John 4:14). Yet, the Teacher still finds emptiness, hinting at the insufficiency of earthly provision alone.

verses.text: I bought male and female slaves, and I had slaves born in my house. I also had great herds and flocks, more than anyone who had been before me in Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Earthly abundance and power are presented, but later verses show that status and possessions do not offer true fulfillment. This prefigures Christ's teaching on humility and service (see Matt. 20:26-28).

verses.text: I gathered for myself silver and gold and the treasures of kings and provinces. I acquired singers, both men and women, and many concubines, the delight of the children of man.
verses.comment: The accumulation of luxuries and sensual pleasures underlines the emptiness of overindulgence, and the need for moderation. The desire for delight points ultimately to the fulfillment found in divine worship (Ps. 16:11).

verses.text: So I became great and surpassed all who were before me in Jerusalem. My wisdom remained with me.
verses.comment: Despite surpassing all others, the Teacher preserves wisdom as a guiding principle, foreshadowing the value of spiritual discernment over worldly achievement.

verses.text: And whatever my eyes desired I did not keep from them. I did not withhold my heart from any pleasure, for my heart found pleasure in all my work, and this was my reward for all my labor.
verses.comment: The Teacher’s enjoyment is described as the fruit of labor, yet the coming verses question its ultimate value—hinting at the need for lasting, spiritual reward rather than temporary pleasure.

verses.text: Then I considered all that my hands had done and the toil I had spent in doing it, and behold, all was vanity and striving after wind, and there was nothing to be gained under the sun.
verses.comment: The Teacher’s final assessment is emptiness of worldly accomplishments—echoed in Jesus’ teaching about the emptiness of gaining the world but forfeiting one’s soul (Matt. 16:26).

verses.text: So I turned to consider wisdom and madness and folly—for what can anyone do who comes after the king? Only what has already been done.
verses.comment: The cyclical nature of human endeavor reflects a deep realism; true wisdom’s value lies in its ability to discern beyond worldly repetition.

verses.text: Then I saw that wisdom excels folly as light excels darkness.
verses.comment: Wisdom’s superiority is depicted through the metaphor of light and darkness, an image later fulfilled in Christ as the Light of the world (see John 1:4-9).

verses.text: The wise person has eyes in his head, but the fool walks in darkness. Yet I realized that the same fate happens to them both.
verses.comment: Even wisdom cannot prevent death; the Teacher is confronting the reality that mortality levels all distinctions—a theme which encourages hope in the promised resurrection.

verses.text: Then I said in my heart, 'What happens to the fool will happen to me also. Why then have I been so wise?' And I said in my heart that this also is vanity.
verses.comment: Intellectual achievement cannot control basic human destiny; the perceived futility calls one to seek deeper meaning through communion with God.

verses.text: For of the wise as of the fool there is no lasting remembrance, seeing that in the days to come all will be forgotten. How the wise dies just like the fool!
verses.comment: Human legacy fades; only spiritual union with God ensures that we are remembered eternally (see Luke 10:20).

verses.text: So I hated life, because the work that is done under the sun was grievous to me, for all is vanity and striving after wind.
verses.comment: This deep weariness reflects the existential crisis of fallen humanity—emphasizing the need for supernatural hope. The phrase 'under the sun' points to a life lived apart from transcendent purpose.

verses.text: I hated all my toil by which I had toiled under the sun, because I must leave it to someone who will come after me.
verses.comment: Nothing can be permanently accrued; inheritance highlights the impermanence of earthly riches. Spiritual inheritance, however, is secured by sacramental union with God’s covenant people.

verses.text: And who knows whether he will be wise or a fool? Yet he will be master over all for which I toiled and used my wisdom under the sun. This too is vanity.
verses.comment: Worldly achievements are vulnerable to mismanagement; true riches are those that endure beyond physical death (Matt. 6:20).

verses.text: So I turned away and gave my heart up to despair over all the toil of my labors under the sun.
verses.comment: The despair described here shows the limits of human achievement and points toward the need for hope and joy given by God through supernatural means.

verses.text: For sometimes a person who has toiled with wisdom and knowledge and skill must leave it all to someone who has not worked for it. This also is vanity and a great evil.
verses.comment: The injustice of inheritance without merit reveals the futility of relying solely on earthly accomplishments; this motivates spiritual practices that prepare one for eternal reward.

verses.text: For what does anyone gain from all their toil and striving with which they toil under the sun?
verses.comment: The question highlights human limitation and echoes Christ’s teaching on anxiety over earthly matters, pointing instead to reliance on God.

verses.text: For all his days are pain and sorrow, and even at night his heart does not rest. This also is vanity.
verses.comment: Restlessness is intrinsic to a life without God’s peace; only spiritual communion can satisfy the heart and provide rest (see Matt. 11:28-30).

verses.text: There is nothing better for a person than that he should eat and drink and find enjoyment in his work. This also, I saw, is from the hand of God.
verses.comment: Enjoyment of daily life is a gift given by God; this echoes the theology of receiving grace through the rhythm of work, feasting, and rest, which finds deeper fulfillment in the sacramental life.

verses.text: For who can eat and who can find enjoyment apart from Him?
verses.comment: True joy comes only through union with God; this verse anticipates the teaching of Christ about abiding in Him as the source of all lasting fulfillment.

verses.text: For to the one who pleases Him, God gives wisdom and knowledge and joy; but to the sinner He gives the task of gathering and collecting, only to give it to the one who pleases God. This also is vanity and striving after wind.
verses.comment: God sovereignly distributes both blessing and frustration according to His wisdom. This points to the importance of living life aligned to God’s will as revealed and made accessible through the Church’s teaching and sacraments. The verse hints at mystery: prosperity and purpose come through pleasing God, not merely through human effort or achievement.
